text:
With security turned on through "sandbox" or by starting in secure mode, by 
default the app is supposed to get read permission to the area under its doc-
root.  When I try this, the generated servlet corresponding to my JSP page 
seems to get default Java security permissions from tomcat.policy.  It does not 
seem to get the permissions that PolicyInterceptor grants to the context.

I am also using a PolicyLoader in my Context definition, but adding permissions 
to that policy file does not help.
creator: ed_barton@i2.com

text:
The only "supported" mechanism to add permissions is via "normal" policy
file, and this seems to work. We had various experiments on adding 
permissions via server.xml, but this had many problems. 
Tomcat3.3 is using standard ( unmodified ) URLClassLoader ( for servlets
and for JSP). The main reason for using tomcat.policy is that this file is 
well documented and most people are supposed to be familiar with it ( instead
of our "proprietary" config formats ).

Please let us know if setting permissions via tomcat.policy fails - it would 
be a serious bug.
